;;一大群抗议者挥舞着西班牙国旗和欧洲国旗
;

;数万人西班牙各地的人们聚集在一起，抗议代理政府计划通过特赦那些参与非法和失败行动的人来确保连任;六年前推动加泰罗尼亚独立;。

;

;拟议的大赦法，这将适用于参与单方面脱离西班牙的数百人，已经导致;执政的西班牙社会主义工人党（PSOE）马德里总部外发生一系列暴力抗议活动;。

;

;西班牙社会党领导人兼看守总理佩德罗·桑切斯认为，在 2017 年动荡的政治和领土危机之后，宽大处理措施将有助于促进共存，但他的反对者谴责此举是一种愤世嫉俗和自私自利的继续掌权的手段。

;

;在;7 月不确定的大选;。尽管保守派人民党 (PP) 名列第一，;事实证明，即使有极右翼 Vox 党和其他较小团体的支持，它也无法组建政府。

;

;但是，西班牙社会工人党 (PSOE)及其左翼苏马尔联盟的合作伙伴 ;通过承诺对加泰罗尼亚两大支持独立的主要政党进行大赦，以换取他们的支持，从而获得了必要的支持;。桑切斯现在预计将在本周末的辩论和投票中赢得国会批准，重新被任命为总理。

;

;周日，全国各地的城镇都举行了抗议活动，包括马德里、巴塞罗那、塞维利亚和巴伦西亚。

;

;聚集在首都太阳门广场的人们举着桑切斯的匹诺曹肖像，高呼“佩德罗·桑切斯进监狱”，并举着横幅，上面写着：“西班牙的民主正处于危险之中” ”、“桑切斯叛徒”和“不对恐怖主义进行特赦——欧洲拯救我们”。

;

;人民党称有 50 万人参加了马德里集会，而中央政府驻该地区的代表称出席人数为 8 万人.

;

;人民党领导人阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费乔在太阳门发表讲话，再次指责桑切斯“收买他的授职权，以换取他的伙伴司法不受惩罚”，并表示西班牙人不会对桑切斯的行为保持沉默。

;

;“西班牙首相办公室不能成为买卖的对象，”费约说。 “西班牙人想要民主、平等、正义和尊严。西班牙从未出卖过自己，而[西班牙工人社会党]也试图掩盖他们失败的事实。西班牙首相永远是赢得选举的人。”

;
;

;;相关：;;卡尔斯·普伊格德蒙特：从自我放逐到不太可能成为西班牙政治的国王;;

;

;他的同事、马德里地区民粹主义人民党主席伊莎贝尔·迪亚斯·阿尤索 (Isabel Díaz Ayuso) 走得更远，告诉群众桑切斯终于揭露了他的“极权主义”计划。

;

;“他是决定无论西班牙付出什么代价，他都不会失去权力；任何人、任何人都不会从他手中夺走它，”她说。 “他决定破坏游戏规则，镇压机构和国家权力。”

;

;Vox 领导人圣地亚哥·阿巴斯卡 (Santiago Abascal) 将桑切斯与加泰罗尼亚各方的协议描述为“一场大写字母的政变”并表示这是“过去40年来西班牙政治最微妙的时刻”。他还呼吁进行“永久、和平的动员”，这远远超出周日的一次性示威活动。

;

;桑切斯本人已敦促人民党表现出“良好的判断力”，并停止试图煽动事态。< /p>;

;“我要求他们尊重投票箱的结果以及我们即将组建的政府的合法性，” ;他周六说道。 “我要求他们勇敢起来，对极右翼的熊抱说不，并放弃他们目前正在走向深渊的反动道路。我们将为所有西班牙人执政——争取四年的社会进步和共存。”

;

;;伊丽莎白·博恩穿着黑色夹克看着镜头
;

;数万人，包括在法国各地反犹太事件急剧增加以及围绕是否以及如何参加的激烈政治争论中，预计许多高级政治家将在巴黎游行反对反犹太主义。

;

;“我将为反对反犹太主义而游行。法国总理伊丽莎白·博恩（Elisabeth Borne）在 X（以前称为 Twitter）上写道，她的犹太父亲在第二次世界大战期间被驱逐出境。 “这场战斗对于我们的民族凝聚力至关重要。”

;

;内政部长杰拉尔德·达尔马宁 (Gérald Darmanin) 表示，将部署 3,000 多名警察和宪兵，以维持“伟大的公民游行”沿线的安全。从巴黎左岸的奥赛码头到首都市中心的卢森堡花园。

;

;法国是欧洲最大的犹太和穆斯林社区的所在地，自 10 月 7 日以来，紧张局势不断升级巴勒斯坦激进组织哈马斯对以色列的袭击，以及以色列随后对加沙地带长达一个月的轰炸。

;

;自冲突开始以来，已记录了超过 12,250 起反犹太主义行为，其中至少有 73 起反对反犹太主义的示威活动预计周日将在全国各地举行，包括斯特拉斯堡、里昂和马赛等城市。

;

;法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 表示，他不会参加，但会“在我的心里和我的心中”。马克龙在《巴黎人报》发表的一封信中谴责了“无法忍受的事情”，法国必须“团结在其价值观和普世主义之下”。肆无忌惮的反犹太主义在法国死灰复燃”。他说：“让我们的犹太公民感到害怕的法国不是法国。”

;

;两任前总统弗朗索瓦·奥朗德和尼古拉·萨科齐以及几位前总理预计将参加游行。前足球运动员莉莲·图拉姆和作家马克·利维也将出席。

;

;在写着“为了共和国，反对反犹太主义”的横幅后面，巴黎游行队伍将由马克龙党成员雅埃尔·布劳恩-皮维 (Yaël Braun-Pivet) 领导。中间派复兴党和国民议会议长，以及来自中右翼反对派共和党的参议院议长热拉尔·拉彻。

;

;但游行因政党之间关于是否参加的激烈分歧而蒙上阴影。 。极右翼全国集会 (RN)，最近对以色列的支持是 ;肯尼亚基利菲县的志愿者在清洁活动中收集塑料垃圾。 ;

;政府代表团将齐聚肯尼亚内罗毕，敲定第一个解决塑料污染危机的全球条约的细节。

;

;周一讨论的一个关键焦点将是限制塑料生产的目标是否应单方面决定，还是各国应选择自己的目标；环保人士称，这是该条约雄心勃勃的“重心”。

;

;国际谈判委员会 (INC) 于 5 月在巴黎举行的最后一轮谈判中，;美国、沙特阿拉伯、印度和中国倾向于“巴黎式”协议;，各国可以自由决定自己的承诺，而包括非洲和许多发展中国家在内的其他国家则更倾向于强有力的全球承诺。

;

;但是一些观察家表示，有迹象表明美国在这一关键问题上的立场发生了转变，但细节尚未公布。美国绿色和平组织全球塑料运动负责人格雷厄姆·福布斯表示：“在 INC2（巴黎谈判）之后，许多环保组织的主要收获是，就巴黎式的自愿承诺而言，美国的立场是多么糟糕。”他说已经出现了转变的信号。

;

;“我们将密切关注，看看结果如何。我们需要谈论规则并制定法规。”

;

;上个月，INC 发布了文本的“零草案”版本，作为就联合国首脑的谈判基础环境计划署称其为自 2015 年《巴黎协定》以来最重要的多边条约。目标是在 2024 年底前达成正式条约。第三轮会谈将于 11 月 13 日至 17 日在肯尼亚举行，标志着一半。

;

;“零草案”体现了不同政府的许多不同观点。在与原生塑料生产有关的部分中，草案提出了致力于减少原生塑料的三种选择。第一个涉及全球商定的减排目标（类似于《蒙特利尔议定书》）。第二个涉及全球减产目标，并由国家确定限制，类似于《巴黎协定》。第三种涉及国家确定的目标和限制。

;

;环境调查局的高级律师蒂姆·格拉比尔 (Tim Grabiel) 表示，希望出现介于选项一和选项二之间的情况：“《蒙特利尔议定书》被普遍认为是世界上最好的多边环境协议，”格拉比尔说。 “我们从巴黎协议中知道，第二个选项行不通。如果你看看全球的盘点，就会看到有记录以来最热的夏天，这可能是我们余生中最冷的夏天，《巴黎协定》的缺点正在变得显而易见。”

;

; “这是雄心勃勃的重心，下周我们将看到各国跌倒的地方。”但是，他承认，“地缘政治在这个问题上非常困难。大型石油和化工公司根本没有做出任何让步。”

;

;根据 2022 年的一份报告，塑料废物正在加速增长，预计到 2060 年将增加近两倍，其中约一半最终进入垃圾填埋场，不到五分之一得到回收利用经济合作与发展组织报告。

;

;绿色和平组织呼吁到 2040 年将塑料产量减少至少 75%，以将温室气体排放控制在 1.5 摄氏度的范围内。

; >;

;世界自然基金会全球塑料政策负责人埃里克·林德约格 (Eirik Lindebjerg) 表示，“零草案”涵盖了一些可能产生影响的“良好具体措施”，以及一些模糊、自愿和不具约束力的条款。重要的是，它为讨论全球禁令创造了一条途径，他说。

;

;“尽管遇到了挫折，但令我深受鼓舞的是，绝大多数国家都在这一过程中表示，他们希望Lindebjerg 表示：“他们制定了一项具有约束力规则的强有力条约，并提出了逐步淘汰材料的全球基础。”

;

;“维持现状符合巨大的经济利益，”他说。 “但公众也对这些利益提出了强烈的抗议和压力。我们将看看最终谁会获胜。”

;

;本月，终结塑料污染雄心勃勃联盟的 60 名部长，;发表联合声明;，重申承诺到 2040 年消除塑料垃圾，并签署一项基于塑料全生命周期的条约。他们对预计管理不善的塑料废物将增加近一倍以及产量增加将导致塑料系统的温室气体排放量增加 60% 表示“深切关注”。

;;意大利小镇的狮子
;

;一头狮子在意大利海滨小镇的街道上徘徊，寻找逃离当地马戏团几个小时后，被注射镇静剂并被捕。

;

;罗马附近拉迪斯波利市的市长亚历山德罗·格兰多 (Alessandro Grando) 告诉居民周六待在家里，而警察和马戏团工作人员则试图抓捕

; ;

;意大利媒体后来发布的视频，显然是当地人拍摄的，但未经卫报认证，显示成年狮子走过黑暗和荒凉的街道。

;

;在晚上 10.30 左右（格林尼治标准时间 2130）左右发布的 Facebook 帖子中，距离他最初发布消息已经过去了五个多小时格兰多发出警报，说这只狮子已被“注射镇静剂并被捕获”。

;

;“现在他将被马戏团工作人员带走，”他写道，并感谢在“这些时期提供帮助的紧急服务人员和志愿者”。 ”。

;

;“我希望这一事件能够唤起一些人的良知，希望我们最终能够结束马戏团中对动物的剥削”，市长补充道。

; < p>;考虑到居民的投诉，他早些时候表示，他没有授权镇上出现狮子马戏团，但也表示他无权阻止。

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 20:22:01 +0800 Far-right clashes in London not caused by Braverman remarks, says Shappshttps://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/nov/12/far-right-clashes-london-pro-palestine-march-grant-shapps-suella-braverman
;;2023-11-12T10:50:16Z;
;
;;格兰特·沙普斯在阵亡将士纪念日佩戴罂粟花
;

;伦敦极右翼抗议活动造成九人抗议格兰特·沙普斯认为，警察受伤与苏埃拉·布雷弗曼的言论无关，因为在广泛呼吁解雇内政大臣的情况下，政府开始明显地为她辩护。

;

;;周六纪念碑周围的暴力场景;，极右翼团体与警察发生冲突，据称是对更大规模的亲巴勒斯坦示威活动的反抗议，工党称布雷弗曼故意加剧紧张局势并削弱警察的力量。

;

;但国防部长沙普斯表示，暴力事件警方称主要是足球流氓造成的，与布雷弗曼的言论无关;称;亲巴勒斯坦示威为“仇恨游行”并;指责警方;对左翼抗议活动的处理不够有力。

;

;沙普斯还辩称，虽然 126 人被捕中的大部分人周六，在极右翼人群中，这种情况可能会改变，因为警察仔细研究了亲巴勒斯坦游行中看似反犹太标语牌和口号的镜头。

;

;被问及布雷弗曼是否部分激怒了极右翼分子。正确的暴力——大都会警察似乎采取的观点，;其中说;“围绕抗议和治安进行了一周的激烈辩论”加剧了紧张局势 - 沙普斯说事实并非如此。

;

;“反抗议已经要发生了，”他在周日的节目中告诉天空电视台的特雷弗·菲利普斯。 “那些本周末打算过来破坏的人已经说过他们会这么做。他们以自己扭曲的方式这样做，因为他们是在抗议其他游行。”

;

;沙普斯表示，他预计亲巴勒斯坦游行“仍将逮捕更多人”——这吸引了估计有 300,000 人参加，并在停战日静默后远离和平纪念碑举行——“仅仅是因为警察[被极右暴力]分散了注意力，或者因为他们无法立即干预”。

;

;布雷弗曼的辩护将被视为一个迹象，表明里希·苏纳克(Rishi Sunak)无意立即解雇她，尽管在她向《泰晤士报》提交了一篇有关游行的文章，反抗第10号之后，有人呼吁他这样做;没有按照唐宁街的要求进行更改;。;。 p>;

;有人猜测 ;高级保守党警告称，如果苏纳克未能解雇布雷弗曼，他的实力将被削弱< /a>;

; ;

;“以前没有内政大臣这样做过。她的工作应该是支持警方并与警方合作并平息紧张局势。她却反其道而行之。她以一种非常具有破坏性和不负责任的方式做了相反的事情。”

;

;当被问及布雷弗曼是否应该辞职时，库珀说：“她一开始就不应该做这份工作。”

; < p>;凯尔·斯塔默在《星期日电讯报》的一篇隔夜评论文章中表示，布雷弗曼最近的评论，包括将无家可归描述为“生活方式的选择”，表明“完全缺乏对这个国家的价值观及其原则的尊重”。

;

;他写道：“最近，在公共生活中，很少有人比苏埃拉·布雷弗曼（Suella Braverman）更煽动分裂、让英国人民相互对立、播下仇恨和不信任的种子。这样做，她贬低了她的办公室。”

;

;伦敦工党市长萨迪克·汗在《星期日镜报》上撰文表示，如果苏纳克不解雇布雷弗曼，“他太软弱了，或者同意她的观点” .

;

;然而，解雇布雷弗曼会;立即激怒了她的保守党右翼盟友。其中一位，德维齐斯议员丹尼·克鲁格，;表示;周末的主要教训是“也许如果[亲巴勒斯坦]游行不被允许继续进行，那就最好了”。

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 19:22:02 +0800 ‘Violent colonialist’ Magellan is unfit to keep his place in the night sky, say astronomershttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/nov/12/violent-colonialist-magellan-is-unfit-to-keep-his-place-in-the-night-sky-say-astronomers
;;2023-11-12T07:00:14Z;
;
;;澳大利亚维多利亚州塔斯曼海上空银河系右侧的大麦哲伦星云和小麦哲伦星云。
;

;几个世纪以来，斐迪南·麦哲伦一直被赋予罕见的特权。探险家的名字已写在星星上。我们银河系的两个卫星星系在南半球上空闪闪发光，被标记为大麦哲伦星云和小麦哲伦星云。

;

;现在天文学家想要消除这种天体区别。他们说，16 世纪的葡萄牙水手麦哲伦是一名杀人犯，他在领导第一次环球航行期间奴役并烧毁了土著人民的家园。他们坚持认为他的名字不应该再因与云有关而受到尊重。

;

;“麦哲伦犯下了可怕的行为。在后来的关岛和菲律宾，他和他的手下烧毁了村庄并杀害了居民。”马萨诸塞州阿默斯特学院的天文学家米娅·德洛斯·雷耶斯说道。麦哲伦于 1519 年领导了西班牙探险队，实现了欧洲人首次经由太平洋到达亚洲的航行，但在 1521 年与现今菲律宾土著人民的一场战斗中身亡。

;

;在期刊中的一篇文章中 < em>;APS 物理学;，雷耶斯呼吁国际天文学联合会——负责天体命名的机构——重新命名麦哲伦云。 “我和许多其他天文学家认为，天文物体和设施不应该以麦哲伦的名字命名，也不应该以任何有暴力殖民主义遗产的人的名字命名。”

;

;不仅仅是麦哲伦的行为应该导致他的名字被命名。纽约大学的大卫·霍格教授认为，它是从天空中剥离出来的。 “主要问题是云不是他的发现，”他告诉 Space.com 网站。

; ;

;南半球的原住民可以清楚地看到这些物体，并为它们起了自己的名字。事实上，直到 19 世纪末，它们才以探险家的名字命名。

;

;“当我们维护像麦哲伦这样的人的名字时，他们的生活和遗产积极造成了伤害，我们就疏远了他们。”雷耶斯补充道，呼吁变革是日益激烈的命名革命中的最新一场战斗，研究人员要求对现在被认为令人反感的科学名称进行更改。正如《观察家报》上周透露的那样，其中包括以希特勒和墨索里尼命名的物种，许多科学家认为不应再使用这些标签。因此，他们敦促分类组织允许对被视为冒犯性的名称进行更改。

;

;目前尚不清楚麦哲伦云可以有哪些替代名称。银河云作为一项建议被提出。

;

;但是这个过程会在哪里停止呢？这位探险家还以他的名字命名了两台 6.5 米麦哲伦望远镜和即将建成的巨型麦哲伦望远镜，这些望远镜均位于智利。雷耶斯也迫切要求重新命名。

;

;此外，地球上最独特的水体之一是以探险家的名字命名的，但麦哲伦海峡是否有可能被赋予新名称？

;

;科学家表示，未来在命名恒星或物种时必须更加谨慎，许多人认为这些不应再回忆起个体。他们提到了美国宇航局的火星机器人漫游车——好奇号、毅力号和精神号——它们反而尊重理想。

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 16:52:01 +0800 Emmanuel Macron pledges €1bn to fund research into melting ice capshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/12/emmanuel-macron-pledges-1bn-to-fund-research-into-melting-ice-caps

;
;;浮冰上的两只北极熊
;

;法国将花费 10 亿欧元（8.8 亿英镑）从现在到 2030 年，科学界对世界冰盖和冰川融化的关注迅速增加。

;

;一艘新的极地科学船将带头开展这项工作，法国呼吁暂停对极地研究的开发。迄今为止，英国、加拿大、巴西和其他 19 个国家已签署了该协议。

;

;法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 在巴黎举行的国家元首和科学家峰会上表示：“我们不谈论的是明天的威胁，但这种威胁已经存在并且正在加速。我们正在谈论冰冻圈[地球的冰]的转变，它已经威胁到了数百万人，并将威胁到数十亿地球上的居民，并带来多种直接和间接后果。”

;

;地球极地地区和冰川的困境引起了许多科学家的警惕，如 ;去年首次出现在两极的热浪;，看起来将经常发生。

;

;今年是;已经是有记录以来最热门的; 可能还有 ;hottest in 100,000 years;, with ocean temperatures so far above normal as to be, in the words of one scientist, ;“gobsmackingly bananas”;.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Major sea-level rise caused by melting of Greenland ice cap is 'now inevitable';

;
;

;The Earth's ice caps reflect much of the sun's light back into space, ;known as the “albedo effect”;, and the melting ice leaves dark sea that absorbs more heat, making the disappearing ice a ;potential tipping point for the climate; that would cause a rapid increase in heating. John Kerry, the US special presidential envoy for climate, did not attend the Paris summit but sent a video message in which he warned of the consequences. “We must understand the tipping points, the points which there is no reclaiming, there is no coming back,” he said.

;

;Some scientists now believe that only drastic measures can avoid the worst. Among them is Sir David King, former UK chief scientist, and now head of the Centre for Climate Repair at Cambridge University, who is researching ;ways to refreeze the Arctic ocean;.

;

;Macron called the high-level meeting of heads of state from countries with polar territory or that have glaciers, accompanied by leading scientists, in Paris on Friday.

;

;They heard from polar and glacier experts that temperatures were rising four times more rapidly in the Arctic than the global average, half the world's 200,000 glaciers were set to disappear by the end of the century and that the rate of sea level rise had ;doubled in the last two decades;.

;

;Pam Pearson, founder and director of the International Cryosphere Climate Initiative, a thinktank, warned of the urgency: “Politicians think that the ice is far away. The ice does not care. It will continue melting until carbon dioxide levels stop rising and come down. But they are still rising just as fast as they were 20 years ago. Scientists are screaming that this is insanity.”

;

;Macron, seated opposite her, looked grave, as Pearson, who spent 20 years as a US diplomat working on conflict and geopolitical concerns, continued: “I know that climate change is seen as a soft issue [compared with wars and national security]… but we can't negotiate with the melting point of ice.”

;

;France, which is home to glaciers in its Alpine departments, and has territory and a science base in Antarctica, has taken a leading role in pushing for agreement at; this year's UN Cop28 climate summit in Dubai;, which starts at the end of this month. Macron also hosted a ;summit focused on climate finance in June;,where he joined the prime minister of Barbados, Mia Mottley, to call for trillions of dollars of investment in the developing world.

;

;Glaciers were ;melting across the world;, warned the head of the World Meteorological Organisation, Petteri Taalas. As they vanish irrecoverably, more than 1 billion people who depend on them for water and agriculture will face increasingly severe shortages. As well as cutting greenhouse gas emissions overall, there are also urgent measures that scientists believe could be taken now that would reduce or delay the risk of the collapse of glaciers or a tipping point at the poles.

;

;Soot, for instance, ;is a significant problem in the melting of ice;. Also known as black carbon, it is a byproduct of combustion that stains the ice and has a darkening effect that causes more heat to be absorbed. Large, miles-long streaks of soot on Arctic ice are now clearly visible from aerial images. Scientist say cleaning up air pollution by stopping burning coal would have an immediate impact on soot and could halt or delay a substantial amount of melting. ;Another focus is methane;, a greenhouse gas 80 times more powerful than carbon dioxide in its warming effect, but which breaks down much faster in the atmosphere. Scientists calculate that reducing methane, soot and other “short-lived climate pollutants” ;could slow warming by 0.24C by 2050;.

;

;Methane is expected to be one of the areas of focus at the; forthcoming Cop28 UN climate summit;. Some experts are pushing for the hosts, the major oil and gas producer United Arab Emirates, to try to broker a deal with other major oil producing countries and companies to reduce the leakage of methane from fossil fuel operations.

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 16:22:01 +0800 Floating factories of artificial leaves could make green fuel for jets and shipshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/12/floating-factories-artificial-leaves-green-fuel-jets-ships-carbon-dioxide
;;2023-11-12T07:00:14Z;
;
;;The artificial leaves were tested on the River Cam in and around Cambridge including sites such as the Bridge of Sighs.
;

;Automated floating factories that manufacture green versions of petrol or diesel could soon be in operation thanks to pioneering work at the University of Cambridge. The revolutionary system would produce a net-zero fuel that would burn without creating fossil-derived emissions of carbon dioxide, say researchers.

;

;The Cambridge project is based on a floating artificial leaf which has been developed at the university and which can turn sunlight, water and carbon dioxide into synthetic fuel. The group believe these thin, flexible devices could one day be exploited on a industrial scale.

;

;“Solar panels are excellent at generating electricity and are making a great contribution to the world reaching its net zero aspirations,” said ;Erwin Reisner;, the professor of energy and sustainability at Cambridge University. “But using sunlight to make non-fossil fuels that could be burned by cars or ships takes things a stage further.”

;

;Reisner and his colleagues envisage exploiting the technology to build carpets of artificial leaves that would float on lakes and river estuaries, and use sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide into the components of petrol and other fuels. “The crucial point is that we are not decarbonising the economy through techniques like these,” Reisner said. “Carbon is still a key component. What we are doing is to 'defossilise' the economy. We will no longer be burning ancient sources of carbon – coal, oil and gas – and adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere, a process that is doing so much damage at present.”

; ;

;The artificial leaf created at Cambridge takes its inspiration from plants, which use photosynthesis to create food. An early prototype consisted of chemical light absorbers and catalysts that turned carbon dioxide and water into a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen. This combination is known industrially as syngas and it is an intermediary in the production of many chemicals and fuels.

;

;It was a crucial first step. But the device consisted of cumbersome glass sections and protective coatings. Improvements were needed and were made by exploiting thin-film metal oxides and materials called perovskites to create devices that were covered with micrometre-thin, water-repellent layers. The result was a highly effective but non-bulky device that is a millimetre thick and covers an area of 100 square centimetres, a bit like a leaf.

;

;Floated on water, the artificial leaf produces hydrogen and carbon monoxide. “Crucially, we use sunlight to power these transformations,” said Reisner. “And the chemicals that we make this way have already been used to manufacture feedstocks, though it is fuel – like diesel or petrol – that we really want to target. One goal would be to make green sustainable kerosene for the aviation market.”

;

;Ships are another target. About 80% of global trade is transported by cargo vessels that burn fossil fuels and their emissions account for more than 3% of the world's total industrial output of carbon dioxide. Substituting their fuel with an effective green alternative would play a big role in helping in the battle against global heating.

;

;A crucial advantage of this technology is the fact that it floats and so does not occupy the large amounts of land needed for crops and woodlands. “Clean energy and land use would not be competing with each other,” he added.

;

;Floating farms of solar fuel leaves could also supply coastal settlements and islands, and exploit water in industrial ponds and irrigation canals.

;

;“You could roll up these devices and put them almost anywhere you wanted,” Reisner said. “They are fantastically flexible.”

;

;The team have now created a startup company to commercialise these inventions. “We have taken the science of these systems as far as we can and it is now up to engineers to scale them up so that they can be used on scales large enough to have an impact on carbon emissions,” Reisner told the ;Observer;.

;

;“We need to take solar chemistry from the laboratory and take it to a large-scale industrial level, and that will take millions of pounds of investment.”

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 15:52:02 +0800 Nasa’s hunt for signs of life on Mars divides experts as mission costs rockethttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/nov/12/experts-split-over-nasa-mission-to-mars-costs-rocket
;;2023-11-12T05:00:11Z;
;
;;Santa Cruz hill on the surface of Mars
;

;It is one of the most complex space missions ever contemplated. A flotilla of unmanned probes and robot rovers will be ;flown to Mars to gather rock samples; which will then be blasted back to Earth for study for signs of life.

;

;This is Nasa's Mars Sample Return and it would involve the first-ever space launch from another planet, as well as the first-ever rendezvous in orbit around another planet.

;

;But this massively ambitious mission is in trouble. Its costs have spiralled dramatically and an independent review panel – set up by the space agency – has just warned that the mission's original $4.4bn price tag is likely to soar to $8-11bn. A swath of other Nasa missions could be cancelled as a result.

;

;“The Mars Sample Return was established with unrealistic budget expectations,” says the panel's report. “There is currently no credible, congruent technical, nor properly margined schedule, cost and technical baselines that can be accomplished with the likely available funding.” In fact, there is “near zero probability” of Nasa's plan succeeding on its current budget, the board concluded.

;

;To the fury of a number of space scientists, the mission's spiralling costs are already playing a part in the postponement of other Nasa-funded projects. These include Veritas, ;a mission to study Venus; to discover why this searingly hot planet lost its potential to be a habitable world.

;

;Another victim has been the Geospace Dynamics Constellation mission for studying the upper atmosphere. “You are cutting the artery, the lifeblood of our science,” plasma physicist Allison Jaynes of Iowa University told the journal ;Science;. “All of Nasa science is taking a hit because of the Mars Sample Return burden.”

;

;The mission will rely on ;the robot rover Perseverance;, which is currently trundling across the red planet collecting samples of Martian rock. These are placed in titanium tubes, each the size of a hot dog, and stored. In a few years, the agency envisages putting a lander, currently developed by Lockheed Martin, on Mars.

; ;

;Perseverance would place its stockpile of containers into this lander which would then be sent back into space and placed in orbit around Mars while a third craft – an Earth return orbiter, built by the European Space Agency (Esa) – would pick up the tubes of rock and ferry them back to Earth. A small probe would parachute the samples down to waiting scientists, possibly by 2033 at the earliest, says Nasa.

;

;Unfortunately, the space agency initially underestimated the size of the spacecraft that would be needed to take the samples off the surface of Mars. In addition, it failed to realise the highly complex steps that would have to be taken to prevent Earthly bacteria or viruses from contaminating Martian soil samples, while also guarding against possible Martian lifeforms infecting Earth.

;

;Inflation and supply shortages are also reported to have triggered cost increases.

;

;As a result, several leading scientists have called for the mission to be scrapped, although many others say it should be saved.

;

;The latter group point to the example of the ;James Webb space telescope; which only narrowly survived a series of cancellation calls after its price tag soared from $1bn to $10bn, triggering the postponement of other space missions. However, the telescope is now ;returning breathtaking images of distant stars and galaxies ;and is transforming our knowledge of deep space.

;

;The Mars Sample Return has a similar, transformative potential, said Professor Lewis Dartnell of Westminster University. “At present, we have to seek evidence of past life on Mars by attempting to shrink an entire laboratory to a miniaturised size so it can be fitted with wheels and cameras to trundle across Mars in the hope it can find signs of life.

;
;
;

;The Mars Sample Return will give us the best possible chance of finding evidence that there was once life on Mars

;
; ;Professor Lewis Dartnell, Westminster University;
;
;
;

;“The Mars Sample Return will change all that by making Martian rock available to the most sophisticated analytical laboratories on Earth. That will give us the best possible chance of finding evidence that there was once life on Mars.”

;

;This point was backed by Professor Caroline Smith of the Natural History Museum, London. “We are not going to open one of these samples and find a dinosaur bone there. We are only going to find signs of past primitive life by putting them through a host of physical and chemical tests which, in many cases, can only be done with huge, building-sized instruments like the UK's Diamond Light Source.

;

;“Only when we have done all these tests will we be able to say there is clear evidence a sample contains the remains of once living things.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;'We are all Martians!': space explorers seek to solve the riddle of life on Mars;

;
;

;Scientists now believe Mars was a warm, watery world 4 billion years ago and possessed ideal conditions for the appearance of life. However, the planet later lost its magnetic field, as well as its water and atmosphere, and was battered by intense ultraviolet radiation. Life would have found it difficult to survive.

;

;“Nevertheless, it is important to find out if living things did evolve there in the past, just as it is crucial to discover if they now exist elsewhere in the solar system,” said Professor Andrew Coates, of University College London.

;

;“At present, we know there are seas of water, rich in organics, on Europa, a moon of Jupiter, and on Enceladus, a moon of Saturn.

;

;“Life could have evolved there and we need to investigate these worlds as well – for if we find life is present on these distant moons, and once existed on Mars in the past, we will have very firm evidence that life is ubiquitous across the universe.”

;
;;Catholic bishop Joseph Strickland protests the Los Angeles Dodgers honoring the pro-LGBTQ+ group Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence in June this year.
;

;Pope Francis has dismissed a bishop in Texas, Joseph Strickland, one of his fiercest critics among US Roman Catholic conservatives, the Vatican has said.

;

;It is very rare for a bishop to be relieved of his duties outright. Usually bishops in trouble with the Vatican are asked to resign before submitting a resignation, which the pope accepts.

;

;A pope only makes such a move when a bishop refuses a request to resign and is considered drastic.斯特里克兰现年 65 岁，比主教通常的退休年龄低 10 岁。 Strickland had said earlier this year that he would refuse to resign if asked.

;

;Strickland, a prolific user of social media who was named to the diocese by the late pope, Benedict XVI in 2012, tweeted earlier this year that he rejected Francis' “program undermining the Deposit of Faith”.

;

;He has been particularly critical of the pontiff's attempt to make the ;Catholic church; more ;welcoming to the LGBTQ+ community; and attempts by Francis to give lay people more responsibility in the church and ;opposed a recent synod;.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Pope Francis suggests gay couples could be blessed in Vatican reversal;

;
;

;Saturday's dismissal followed a Vatican investigation earlier this year into the administration of the Tyler diocese, which Catholic media reports said included a review of his handling of financial affairs.

;

;It was announced simultaneously by the Vatican and the US Bishops Conference. Neither statement gave a reason.

;

;There was no immediate response from Strickland. A recording on the diocese's telephone said they were closed for the weekend.

;

;Strickland had become one of the most vocal standard bearers of the ultra-conservative wing of the US Catholic church and has a national following far beyond the small diocese of Tyler in eastern Texas.

;

;Last August, Francis lamented what he called a “reactionary” Catholic church in the United States, where he said political ideology had replaced faith in some cases.

;

;Strickland is a strong supporter of former US president Donald Trump and is seen as a hero by conservative US Catholic media outlets that are aligned with Trump.

;

;Last year, when the Vatican ;defrocked ultra-conservative US anti-abortion priest Frank Pavone ;for “blasphemous” social media posts and disobedience to bishops, Strickland was one of the few American bishops to defend him publicly.

;

;“The blasphemy is that this holy priest is cancelled while an evil president promotes the denial of truth and the murder of the unborn at every turn, Vatican officials promote immorality and denial of the deposit of faith and priests promote gender confusion devastating lives … evil,” Strickland wrote on the platform then known as Twitter.

;

;The Vatican said Francis named the bishop of Austin, Texas, Joe Vasquez, as the interim administrator of the Tyler diocese.
